metadata.title: Selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone on Ni-based catalysts

Selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone on Ni-based catalysts Jing Bai Conceptualization Investigation Methodology Supervision a Canwei Cheng Investigation Writing – original draft Data curation Validation a c Yong Liu Writing – review & editing Formal analysis Supervision Visualization c Chenguang Wang Writing – review & editing Methodology Resources Supervision c Yuhe Liao Formal analysis Writing – review & editing Supervision c Lungang Chen Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition b ⁎ Longlong Ma Project administration Resources b a School of Chemical Engineering and Energy, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China School of Chemical Engineering and Energy Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 China aSchool of Chemical Engineering and Energy, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China b Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control of Ministry of Education, School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control of Ministry of Education, School of Energy and Environment Southeast University Nanjing 210096 China bKey Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control of Ministry of Education, School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China c Key Laboratory of Renewable Energy, Guangzhou Institute of Energy Conversion, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Guangzhou 510640, China Key Laboratory of Renewable Energy, Guangzhou Institute of Energy Conversion Chinese Academy of Sciences Guangzhou 510640 China cKey Laboratory of Renewable Energy, Guangzhou Institute of Energy Conversion, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Guangzhou 510640, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Key Laboratory of Renewable Energy, Southeast University, NO. 2 Wushan Energy Road, Tianhe Di, Guangzhou 510640, China. Key Laboratory of Renewable Energy Southeast University NO. 2 Wushan Energy Road, Tianhe Di Guangzhou 510640 China In this work, Ni-based catalysts were prepared using the impregnation method. Ni/Al2O3 showed good performance with a γ‐valerolactone (GVL) yield of 99.2% from hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA). Among the tested bimetallic catalysts, the NiCo catalyst showed better performance than NiMn, NiMo, and NiCu catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Catalysts with different Ni/Co ratio were synthesized, and 15%Ni-15%Co/Al2O3 shows the best performance with a GVL yield of 99.5%. The textural and chemical characteristics of the NiCo/Al2O3 were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPD). This study shows that the incorporation of the Ni and Co metals formed a Ni-Co alloy, which significantly increased the activity than other Ni-based bimetallic catalysts and led to a milder condition for hydrogenation of LA to GVL. The test of reuse potential of 15%Ni-15%Co/Al2O3 exhibited good stability up to 5 cycles without obvious deactivation. Graphical abstract Selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-Valerolactone over Ni and NiCo catalysts Image, graphical abstract Keywords Levulinic acid γ‐valerolactone Ni NiCo Hydrogenation 1 Introduction Diminishing fossil resource reserves and global-warming issue have caught worldwide attentions [1, 2, 3]. Biomass, a renewable, readily available and carbon-neutral energy resource, can be used to produce fuels and chemicals which is crucial for the sustainable development of mankind [4]. During the last decades, converting biomass to chemicals and fuels has aroused tremendous interest in industrial companies and academia [5]. Generally, biomass is employed to produce food, medicinal drugs, flavors, and fragrances [6, 7]. Among these molecules, levulinic acid (LA) is one of most promising molecules derived from biomass. It can be further converted into γ-valerolactone (GVL), which is a crucial intermediate and has shown great commercial potential due to its applications as a solvent in lacquers and food additives. Both noble metal (Ru, Rh, Pt, Pd, Au) catalysts [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13] and non-precious metal (Ni, Cu, Co) catalysts [14, 15] have been used for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Upare et al. [9] used a continuous down flow fixed-bed reactor to test the catalytic performance of carbon-supported noble metal (Ru, Pt, Pd) catalysts for hydrogenation of LA to GVL and concluded that 5 wt.% Ru/C gave GVL with 100% selectivity at 100% LA conversion up to 240 h without loss in its activity. Du et al. [11] demonstrated that LA could be converted to GVL without the use of external hydrogen over supported-gold catalysts. Yan et al. [12] synthesized a series of catalysts of Pd nanoparticles supported on SiO2 and concluded that the method to fabricate Pd nanoparticles in the presence of liquid CO2 was better than the traditional impregnation method. Although noble metal catalysts have high hydrogenation activity and selectivity, their high price limits their use in large-scale applications. In recent years, studies on the hydrogenation of LA to GVL by non-precious metal catalysts have attracted great attention. Obregón et al. [16] studied the liquid phase hydrogenation of LA on Ni/Al2O3 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with water as solvent. Compared with Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, Ni/Al2O3 catalyst has higher hydrogenation activity. The reaction of GVL reached 92% by reacting at 250 °C and 6.5 MPa H2 pressure for 2 h. Mohan et al. investigated the effect of Ni content on the performance of Ni/H-ZSM-5 for the hydrogenation of LA and found that the catalyst has the best catalytic performance for hydrogenation of LA to GVL when the Ni content was 30% (mass fraction) [17]. Gundeboina et al. [18] also investigated the Ni-Cu/Al2O3 bimetallic mixed oxide catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of LA to GVL and they observed that the GVL yield of 99.8% was achieved at 275 °C, 0.1 MPa H2 when the mole ratio of Ni: Cu: Al=44:22:23. Our recent study proposed a green, simple and inexpensive strategy for in situ synthesis Ni/C catalysts with pomelo peel [19]. This catalyst given a high yield (94.5%) of GVL and exhibited good stability up to 5 cycles without obvious loss of catalytic activity. Although many studies have focused on non-noble monometallic catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, the reaction conditions remain harsh such as high temperature or pressure. Bimetallic catalysts can be superior than monometallic catalysts due to the synergistic effect between metal species, modified electronic state of metals, or enhanced adsorption ability of catalysts [20, 21]. It can lead to a milder reaction condition for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. However, there were few literatures about the bimetallic catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA. In this study, we prepared a series of Ni-based bimetallic catalysts (NiCo, NiCu, NiMn, NiMo) with different supports and investigated their performance for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. We found that NiCo catalysts showed highest activity than other bimetallic catalysts. Various characterizations were employed to understand the high performance of NiCo bimetallic catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2•6H2O, 98.0%), cobalt nitrate in hexahydrate, hexaammonium molybdate, and manganese carbonate were purchased from Guangzhou Chemical Reagent Factory. The pomelo peel was collected from our daily life to prepare the carbon support. The nanometer gama-aluminum oxide, molecular sieve (HZSM-5) and Levulinic acid (LA, 99.0%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. γ-valerolactone (GVL, 98.0%) was purchased from Macklin Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts We synthesized Ni-based catalysts (Ni, NiCo, NiCu, NiMo, and NiMn) with three different support, carbon, Al2O3, and HZSM-5. The carbon support was made using our previous method [22, 23]. Briefly, sliced pomelo peel was dried using a vacuum freeze dryer, which was further grinded and employed as the carbon support. The catalysts were synthesized with impregnation method. 2.1 g catalyst support was impregnated in 18.9 g water, and then nickel nitrate hexahydrate and another metal precursor (cobalt nitrate in hexahydrate, hexaammonium molybdate, or manganese carbonate) were added into the beaker. After stirring for 2 h, the solution was transferred to a 50 ml flask for steaming. After that, the sample was dried in the drying oven for 12 h. Finally, the Al2O3 and HZSM-5 supported dried sample was reduced for 3 h in H2 flow and rate of flow was 20 mL/min at 650 °C. The carbon supported catalysts was in situ reduced by reductant gas (CO) during the preparation processes which was not further reduced. The as-prepared sample was designated as “x-Ni-y-M/Z”. “M” denotes another metal (M = Co, Cu, Mo, and Mn). The “x” and “y” denote the mass fractions of Ni and another metal, respectively. “Z” denotes the catalyst support (C, Al2O3, and HZSM-5). 2.3 Catalytic test The LA hydrogenation was performed in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a heating system and a mechanical stirrer. Firstly, 0.2 g LA and 19.8 g water were added into autoclave. Then, reduced catalyst was immediately added into the autoclave for avoiding oxidation. Then the reactor was sealed, and the air was removed by five times of hydrogen gas exchanges and then the reactor was pressurized to the specified pressure. After that, the reactor was heated to the specified temperature. Finally, when the reaction was over, the reactor was cooled down to the room temperature. The product was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC; Waters e2695) with the Shodex SH1011 sugar column. The mobile phase was 5 mM sulfuric acid aqueous solution with a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min and the column temperature was maintained at 50 °C. The conversion of LA, products selectivity, and total organic carbon (TOC) were calculated using the following equations: (1) Conversion ( % ) = mole of LA consumed / mole of LA feed (2) Yield ( % ) = mole of product produced / mole of LA feed (3) Selectivity ( % ) = mole of product produced / mole of LA consumed (4) TOC ( % ) = mole of carbon in the product / mole of carbon in the converted LA 2.4 Catalytic characterization The crystal structure of the catalyst was examined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). It was performed using an X'pert Pro-Philips diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.1541841 nm). The measurement conditions were in the range of 2θ =10°−80° with a step counting time 10 s and a step size 0.0167° at 298 K. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were carried out using an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (Thermo Electron Corp. Altrincham, UK) equipped with an Al Kα source (1486.6 eV). The binding energies were corrected based on the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of the catalysts was carried out by a multifunctional automatic adsorption instrument (TP-5080, Tianjin Xianquan Industry and Trade Development Co., Ltd.). Prior to reduction, the catalyst (100 mg) was treated at 300 °C (heating rate of 10 °C/min) for 1 h to remove impurities using flowing Helium gas, and then the temperature was reduced to 50 °C before H2 temperature-programmed reduction. After the temperature dropped, the system was raised to 850 °C under H2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The metal loading of the catalyst was tested using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometers (ICP-OES), and it was performed on Optima 8000. Before testing, the catalyst was dissolved by a mixture of concentrated HCl and concentrated HNO3 (VHCl/VHNO3 = 3/1) at room temperature for 1 h and then the dissolved mixture was diluted to a desired concentration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screen and characterization We first tested four carbon-supported Ni-based bimetallic catalysts (NiCo/C, NiCu/C, NiMn/C, and NiMo/C) for hydrolysis of LA. The results are shown in Table 1 . While the NiMo/C (entry 3) shows the lowest activity with 7.2% LA conversion and 2.9% GVL yield, the NiCo/C (entry 1) catalyst shows the highest activity with 89.9% LA conversion and 88.1% GVL yield. NiCu/C (entry 2) and NiMn/C (entry 3) show 44.6% and 36.6% LA conversion, respectively. These different performances are highly likely due to different synergistic effect or electronic structure effect. We then tested another two NiCo catalysts with different supports (ZSM-5 and Al2O3) with results listed in Table 2 . The results suggest that NiCo/Al2O3 (entry 3) has best catalytic performance than NiCo/HZSM-5 (entry 2) and NiCo/C. The acid sites on the surface of catalyst play an role for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL [1]. It is obvious that the acidity of carbon is lower than that of HZSM-5 and Al2O3, [24] while Al2O3 has more Bronsted acid sites than HZSM-5. The differences in acidity of support could contribute to the distinct performance. Alternatively, the support-metal interactions may also contribute to the different activity of catalysts. Nonetheless, the bimetallic catalyst NiCo/Al2O3 was chosen for following studies. We synthesized NiCo/Al2O3 catalysts with different Ni/Co ratio and tested the loadings of Ni and Co using ICP-OES (Table 3 ). Characterization of NiCo/Al2O3 catalysts can help us understand the high performance of NiCo catalysts for LA conversion to GVL. The XRD characterization is showing in the Fig. 1 . The peaks at 2θ = 31.4°, 36.9°, 45.0°, 59.5°, and 65.3° can be ascribed to Co3O4, while the peaks at 2θ = 37.3°, 43.4°, and 62.9° can be ascribed to NiO (Fig. 1A). Interestingly, we observed that a new peak formed at 36.5° ∼36.8° for NiCo/Al2O3 catalysts which is different from pure Co/Al2O3 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. With the increasing loadings of Co, the peak shifted from 36.8° to 36.5° (Fig. 1B). This observation suggests the possible formation of the Ni-Co alloys due to the similar crystal structure, atomic radius, electronegativity and valence between Ni and Co. It also hints the synergistic effect between Ni and Co. We further performed XPS characterization on the catalyst of 15%Ni-15%Co/Al2O3 (Fig. 2 ). From Fig. 2, one can see that in the Co region (Fig. 3 A), there are two predominant peaks at 781.28 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 796.68 eV (Co 2p1/2) with a spin-orbit splitting value of 15.4 eV, while the other two peaks are satellite peaks. The respective peaks of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 corresponds to Co3+ and Co2+, which are consistent with the previous report [25]. The Ni region (Fig. 3B) showed two predominant peaks at 856.98 eV and 874.58 eV with satellite peaks at 862.98 eV and 880.98 eV, which can be ascribed to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2. The spin–orbit splitting value of 17.6 eV between the two main peaks suggested that Ni element in the material has a valence state of +2. Fig. 3 shows the H2 consumption curve of the 15%Ni-15%Co/Al2O3 catalyst at different temperature. The curve can be roughly decomposed into three peaks during the reduction process. Previous study suggested that the initial reduction temperature of Co3O4 occurred at 310 °C, then CoO began to be reduced at 320 °C, and NiO began to be reduced at 345 °C [20]. Therefore, the three peaks can be respectively attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, the reduction of CoO to Co, and the reduction of NiO to Ni. However, Through the calculation of the peak areas of the three reduction peaks, we found that the amount of H2 consumed by the reduction of NiO to Ni was greater than the theoretically required amount of H2. It suggests that the third reduction process could be the co-reduction process of CoO and NiO. Alternatively, it is highly possible due to the reduction process of a mixed oxide formed by Co and Ni oxides. 3.2 Levulinic acid conversion The catalytic performance of NiCo/Al2O3 catalysts was tested for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. We tested the different loadings of Ni and Co for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL (Table 4 ). One can observe improved performances with the increasing loading of Ni species (entries 4–7). The 30%Ni/ Al2O3 also showed a good performance: 99.6% LA conversion and 99.2% GVL yield (entry 1). Among the NiCo bimetallic catalyst, the 15%Ni-15%Co/Al2O3 showed the best performance with the highest GVL yield of 99.5% (entry 4). Based on results in Table 4, we optimized reaction conditions using the catalyst of 15%Ni-15%Co/Al2O3. It was proven that the reaction temperature, reaction time and reaction pressure can affect the GVL yield. Therefore, to determine the optimum reaction conditions, the reaction temperature, pressure, and time were investigated with the results shown in Figs. 4-6 . The Fig. 4 illustrates the tested results on different temperature spanning from 100 °C to 150 °C. It could be seen from the Fig. 4 that both the conversion of LA and the yield of GVL increased significantly and reached 100% and 99.8%, respectively, when the temperature was increased from 100 °C to 110 °C. No significant changes were observed for the further increased temperatures (120∼150 °C). It suggests that 110 °C was the optimized temperature for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL in current catalytic system. H2 pressure as the reductant source plays a critical role in hydrogenation of LA to GVL. The Fig. 5 illustrates the tested results on different H2 pressure spanning from 0.5 MPa to 4.0 MPa. The LA conversion and GVL yield reached approximately 80% when the H2 pressure was 0.5 MPa, suggesting that a mild H2 pressure can facilitate this reaction. Increasing the H2 pressure from 0.5 MPa to 3 MPa, the LA conversion and GVL yield reached 100% and 99.5%, respectively. However, further increased H2 pressure (4 MPa) did not increase the GVL yield. It suggests that a H2 pressure of 3.0 MPa was enough for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. The reaction time was an important factor affecting the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. A shorter reaction time can lead to low GVL yield, while a longer reaction time can cause side reactions. Therefore, we optimized the reaction time and the results were presented in Fig. 6 . From the Fig. 6, we observed that 1.0 h or 1.5 h reaction time is not enough to reach the highest GVL yield in our system. A 99.5% GVL yield and a full conversion of LA were obtained when the reaction time reached 2 h. In addition, negligible changes of GVL yield were observed as the reaction time further increased, indicating that current system can stabilize GVL. To conclude, the optimum reaction conditions of the hydrogenation of LA to GVL were 2 h, 110 °C, and 3 MPa H2, which are milder than the conditions reported in the literatures [26, 27, 28]. More importantly, comparing with alcohol, water is a more suitable solvent for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL because esterification of LA and alcohol will happen at the presence of alcohol [29]. Therefore, this system is beneficial for the industrial application of hydrogenation of LA to GVL. We further focused on reuse potential of the catalyst, which is an indispensable process before any practical applications. The steps for reuse tests of the catalysts were following: after the first reaction, the catalyst was rinsed with deionized water and then dried in a refrigerated vacuum drying oven for 12 h. After that, it was directly added into the reactor for the next reaction. The results for reuse tests are shown in the Fig. 7 . The catalyst showed stable activity for the fifth cycle, which had 90.5% LA conversion and 97.8% GVL selectivity. The conversion rate of LA decreased to 80.1% in the sixth cycle and 71.1% in the seventh cycle, although the GVL selectivity was larger than 95.0%. Previous study suggested that the decrease of LA conversion was due to the Ni leaching [25]. In order to figure out the reason, ICP-OES was used to determine the Ni and Co content in the solution after the 6th cycle. The results showed that the total Ni and Co content in the reaction solution was 1.20 mg and 1.14 mg, respectively, suggesting losses of 5.7% Ni and 5.5% Co. Therefore, it is highly possible that the loss of metal was the main cause of catalyst deactivation. 4 Conclusion In this study, several Ni-based bimetallic catalysts with different supports were screened for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. NiCo/Al2O3 has been found to have the highest activity, achieving high yields of up to 99.5%. Characterizations of the catalyst suggested the formation of the Ni-Co alloy, which afforded enhanced activity. The reaction conditions were optimized and optimum reaction conditions of the hydrogenation of LA to GVL were 2 h, 110 °C, and 3 MPa H2. Meanwhile, the stability of the bimetallic catalysts was investigated, and it exhibited good stability up to five cycles without obvious loss of catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: In this work, Ni-based catalysts were prepared using the impregnation method. Ni/Al2O3 showed good performance with a γ‐valerolactone (GVL) yield of 99.2% from hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA). Among the tested bimetallic catalysts, the NiCo catalyst showed better performance than NiMn, NiMo, and NiCu catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Catalysts with different Ni/Co ratio were synthesized, and 15%Ni-15%Co/Al2O3 shows the best performance with a GVL yield of 99.5%. The textural and chemical characteristics of the NiCo/Al2O3 were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPD). This study shows that the incorporation of the Ni and Co metals formed a Ni-Co alloy, which significantly increased the activity than other Ni-based bimetallic catalysts and led to a milder condition for hydrogenation of LA to GVL. The test of reuse potential of 15%Ni-15%Co/Al2O3 exhibited good stability up to 5 cycles without obvious deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone on Ni-based catalysts
